messages.subject: fundamentalist thinking (was: TCS, was Re: Brain atr...
messages.msgSnippet: My message was not designed to defend fundamentalist Christianity, but to point out that fundamentalist thinking cuts across all types of ideologies (TCS
messages.messageBody:
My message was not designed to defend fundamentalist Christianity,
but to point out that fundamentalist thinking cuts across all types
of ideologies (TCS parenting, unschooling, and homeschooling
included).

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] fundamentalist thinking (was: TCS, was Re: Brain atr...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 5/18/01 3:42:30 PM Mountain Daylight Time, ... In a message designed to defend fundamentalist Christianity, you ended up turning around and
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 5/18/01 3:42:30 PM Mountain Daylight Time,
mother_of_fancy@... writes:


> Those characterizations remind me very
> much of the broadbrush preaching on the religious broadcasts I used
> to listen to. You know, "All homosexuals are pedophiles, etc...."
>
>

In a message designed to defend fundamentalist Christianity, you ended up
turning around and damning it in the same way.

It doesn't help to blame observers for pointing out quotable and documentable
truths. There are MANY fundamentalist Christian writings which condemn
anything except authoritarian discipline, and condemn any homeschooling which
isn't "Christ centered" and parent-directed. No non-Christian could have or
would have made that up, and if things are mentioned which are true, why
revile the reporter?

There are sites and magazines and books that advocate some pretty oppressive
childrearing tactics. I know of not one of them which is not Christian
oriented.

Sandra


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
